Award.AwardTitle: Study of Specific Properties of Hadrons via Precision Experiments at Jefferson Lab
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is focused on two highly rated experimental projects at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility in Virginia. One experiment will measure the proton radius, one of the most fundamental quantities in physics. It is directly related to the structure of the proton, which is a basic constituent block of visible matter. This research will continue the development and construction of a novel hydrogen target to perform a new electron-proton scattering experiment, directly giving the proton radius with higher precision. The second project will measure the lifetime of a particle called the eta meson with high precision, which will be compared with theoretical predictions from the fundamental theory of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). This project will also provide unique opportunities for students, both undergraduate and graduate, to be actively engaged in many different areas of interdisciplinary research: new hardware and cutting-edge software development; large scale data analysis and modern computational problems. In this way the research effort contributes to the development of a much-needed high tech workforce.

As one of the most fundamental quantities in physics, the proton charge radius new independent measurement will have far reaching effect in both atomic and nuclear physics. The currently developed experimental situation with this quantity limits the determination of the Rydberg constant, one of the basic and the most precisely known constant in nature up to now. The experimental results may be sensitive to new physics beyond the Standard Model. The projected 3% accuracy of the eta-meson lifetime measurement will potentially resolve the long-standing discrepancy between the Primakoff-type and electron-positron collider experiments. It will also improve the light quark mass ratio in a direct and model independent way.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this NSF award (PHY-1506388) three major research projects have been carried out by our group: (a) a high precision extraction of the neutral pion life time; (b) the development of an experiment to measure the proton charge radius with a novel independent method and with a high precision to address the current ?proton radius puzzle? in our field of nuclear/particle physics; (c) the development of an experiment to measure one of the light neutral mesons (eta-meson) radiative decay width with a high precision.

The analysis processes for the first experiment (the PrimEx-II experiment at Jefferson Laboratory) was carried out under this award for the past several years. The neutral pion radiative decay width (the life time of this elementary particle) was successfully extracted during this year with an unprecedented 1.5% total uncertainty (see Fig.1).  The neutral pion is the lightest elementary particle consisting of other, more elementary parts (quarks), and its two-gamma decay channel is unique process that undergoing with a violation of fundamental symmetries in Nature, the so-called left-right chiral and axial symmetries. This violation, named as the ?Chiral Anomaly?, is possible only due to the quantum nature of the decay process and cannot be described with a classical physics approach.  Our new result, with its unprecedented accuracy, is proving the validity of the contemporary theory of elementary particles and interactions between them. The results of this experiment have already been presented at APS meetings and an international workshop. It is expected that this new result will have a significant impact on the Particle Data Group?s averaging on this important quantity.

The proton radius ?puzzle? is an effect of a significant disagreement of measurements performed in recent years using two different ?probing? particles: electrons and their heavier partners, the muons. The current situation in this field is such that if the upcoming new experiments prove the existing ?disagreement? then that potentially may indicate a ?new physics? beyond the currently well-established Standard Model in Physics.  The other experimental outcome will make our knowledge on this important quantity more accurate and possibly shifted by the amount of few percent. This will have a similar effect on the value of another more fundamental and the most accurately known constant in physics: the so-called Rydberg constant in theory of hydrogen. Under this award we developed and conducted a new electron-proton scattering experiment at Jefferson Laboratory implementing a magnetic-spectrometer-free method ?

a calorimetric method and normalizing the experimental outcomes to a well-known, pure electromagnetic electron-electron scattering process. These two experimental innovations are applied for the first time in electron proton scattering experiments, and they proved to be the best control of the systematic uncertainties in this type of experiments.  We are (the PRad collaboration) currently analyzing the accumulated rich experimental data set and have already released our preliminary results on the extracted proton charge radius in the APS DNP Hawaii meeting (see Fig. 2). The final results are expected in April of 2019.

Undergraduate and graduate students, as well as, one postdoctoral research scholar research training in our program was supported by other NSF award (PHY-1205962) and it is reported separately.
